summary.p: This manuscript of the Taittirīyopaniṣad in Grantha script is the first of the two parts of Sanscrit 506. The text is interspersed with some notes that act as an index, often marked with a sign before and/or after the note. These notes are printed in Rājendralāla Mitra's edition of the Taittirīyāraṇyaka, and was described by Max Müller in his translation (1879, xxviii), but later editions and translations of the Taittirīyopaniṣad omit it.

The scribe also seems to have marked long vowels that give rise to kampa (Franceschini 2017, 83), using a sign that looks like the syllable bhya. For example, see folio 12v, line 1: yo mā dadāti sa id eva mā[bhya]vāḥha
The microfilm images have been ordered back-to-front.

msItem.title: Taittirīyopaniṣad
msItem.incipit:
śan no mitraś saṃ varuṇaḥ | śan no bhavatvaryyamā | śan na indro bṛhaspatiḥ |
śan no viṣṇururukramaḥ | namo brahmaṇe | namaste vāyo | tva
m eva pratyakṣaṃ brahmāsi | tvam eva pratyakṣaṃ brahma vadiṣyā
mi | ṛtaṃ vadiṣyāmi | satyaṃ vadiṣyāmi | tan mām ava
tu | tadvaktāram avatu | avatu māṃ | avatu va
ktāraṃ | oṃ śāntiś śantiś śāntiḥ | satyaṃ vadiṣyā
mi pañca ca | śīkṣāṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ | varṇṇasvaraḥ | mā
trā balaṃ | sāma santānaḥ | ity uktaś śīkṣādhyāyaḥ | śikṣāṃ panca ca |
msItem.explicit:
śan no maha ity etatra bhīṣāsmād annaṃ bahu kurvīta dvi
catvāriṃśat | hariḥ om | saha nāv avatu | saha nau bhunaktu saha vīryaṃ kara
vāvahai | tejasvi nāvadhītam astu mā vidviṣāvahai | oṃ śāntiś śāntiś śāntiḥ |
